content: The Act is titled the "Truth, Transparency, Accountability, and Fairness in Trade Act". It includes provisions for reporting. Section 163(c) of the Trade Act of 1974 is amended to require the United States International Trade Commission and the Secretary of Labor to submit a joint report to Congress by February 15th each year on the operation of the trade agreements program. The report must include details on exports and imports of goods and services covered by free trade agreements, broken down by volume, industry sector, commodity, and State. The report required by Section 163(c) of the Trade Act of 1974 must include details on exports and imports of goods and services covered by free trade agreements, broken down by volume, industry sector, commodity, and State. It should also compare the data with previous years and forecasts made by the United States Trade Representative. The report required by Section 163(c) of the Trade Act of 1974 must include details on exports and imports of goods and services covered by free trade agreements, broken down by volume, industry sector, commodity, and State. It should also compare the data with previous years and forecasts made by the United States Trade Representative. Additionally, it should provide information on the number of applications filed for adjustment assistance for workers and firms under title II of the Act, the number approved, and the extent of assistance provided as a result of the free trade agreement, nationwide, by State, and industry. The preceding calendar year's agreement should consider the number of years it has been in effect. SEC. 3. TERMINATION OF AGREEMENTS OR PORTIONS THEREOF. Section 125 of the Trade Act of 1974 is amended to include provisions for the termination of free trade agreements if annual reports show export disruption. The Trade Act of 1974 is amended to include provisions for terminating free trade agreements due to rising imports or labor disruptions. The Trade Act of 1974 is amended to include provisions for adjustment assistance for workers and firms affected by free trade agreements, including trade balance disruptions of 5 percent or more. The Trade Act of 1974 is amended to include adjustment assistance for workers and firms impacted by free trade agreements, specifically addressing trade deficit increases of 5 percent or more over consecutive years as a result of the agreement. The Trade Act of 1974 is amended to provide adjustment assistance for workers and firms affected by free trade agreements, focusing on trade deficit increases of 5 percent or more over consecutive years due to the agreement. Congress has the authority to terminate sections of trade agreements related to export, labor, or trade balance disruptions. The Congress has the power to enact rules for the procedure to be followed in each House regarding termination bills related to trade agreements. The rules supersede other rules if inconsistent and can be changed by each House at any time. The Congress has the power to enact rules for the procedure to be followed in each House regarding termination bills related to trade agreements. A termination bill introduced in the House or Senate with respect to a free trade agreement shall be referred to the appropriate committee. No amendments to a termination bill are allowed in either House. The Congress has the power to enact rules for termination bills related to trade agreements. If a committee has not reported a termination bill within 45 days, it will be automatically discharged for consideration and placed on the calendar for a vote within 15 days. The Congress has the power to enact rules for termination bills related to trade agreements. If a termination bill is not reported by the committee within 45 days, it will be automatically discharged for consideration and placed on the calendar for a vote within 15 days. If one House receives a termination bill from the other House, the vote on final passage will be on the termination bill of the other House. In the House of Representatives, a motion to proceed to consider a termination bill is privileged and not debatable. Debate on the bill is limited to 20 hours, divided equally between supporters. In the House of Representatives, motions to limit debate, postpone consideration, or appeal decisions related to termination bills are not debatable and must be decided without debate. In the Senate, consideration of a termination bill is governed by the Rules of the House of Representatives applicable to other bills and resolutions in similar circumstances. Motion to proceed to the consideration of a termination bill is privileged and not debatable, and amendments to the motion are not allowed to move to reconsider the vote. Debate on a termination bill in the Senate and all debatable motions and appeals are allowed. Debate on termination bills in the Senate, including motions and appeals, is limited to 20 hours. Time is divided equally between the majority and minority leaders or their representatives. For debatable motions or appeals related to termination bills, debate is limited to 1 hour, divided between the mover and the bill manager. If the bill manager supports the motion, the minority leader controls the opposition time. The Senate limits debate on termination bills to 20 hours, divided equally between majority and minority leaders. Additional time can be allotted to Senators for debatable motions or appeals. A motion to further limit debate is not debatable, and a motion to recommit a termination bill is not allowed. Consideration of a veto message on a termination bill is limited to 10 hours, divided between the majority and minority leaders. A 'termination bill' refers to a bill introduced in Congress regarding a free trade agreement that has been determined by the Comptroller General to cause export disruption, labor disruption, or trade balance disruption. The bill includes provisions to terminate the agreement within 6 months for specific goods or industries affected, and may require changes in laws or new statutory authorities for cancellation. Authorities must cancel a free trade agreement or specific portions if a termination bill is enacted into law. Future negotiations on the same agreement will not be expedited if renegotiated in a similar form. Authorities must cancel a free trade agreement or specific portions if a termination bill is enacted into law. This includes sections, chapters, or other portions of the trade agreement that led to the determination of export disruption, labor disruption, or trade balance disruption. SEC. 4. RETALIATORY ACTIONS. Amends the Trade Act of 1974 to include retaliatory actions against countries implementing barriers due to termination of a free trade agreement. SEC. 5. SEVERABILITY REQUIREMENT. The United States Trade Representative must ensure that any free trade agreement signed after the enactment of this Act allows for the termination of specific sections for the United States.
